stem: For each assessment finding, click to specify if the finding is consistent with improvement, decline, or no change in the patient's respiratory status.

rationale.correct: Increased oxygen saturation suggests improved gas exchange. Decreased respiratory rate indicates a reduction in the work of breathing. Improved subjective reports of shortness of breath indicates better respiratory function.
rationale.incorrect: Stable or worsening respiratory rate, unchanged oxygen saturation, or increased work of breathing would indicate no change or decline in respiratory status.  A productive cough doesn't necessarily indicate improvement, decline or no change, it is a symptom and requires assessment of other data to determine improvement, decline or no change.

questionTrap.reason: Students may be tempted to focus on a single data point, such as the respiratory rate, without considering other factors like oxygen saturation and patient report.  Students may also incorrectly assume productive cough is indicative of improvement when it requires a bigger picture assessment.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Focusing solely on one vital sign rather than assessing the overall clinical picture.

clinicalPearls: Assess trends in vital signs and respiratory assessment findings rather than isolated values.
Subjective patient reports are important but should be correlated with objective data.
COPD exacerbations require careful monitoring of respiratory status to guide treatment.

itemContext.sbar: Patient is a 68-year-old male with COPD admitted yesterday for an acute exacerbation. He was started on oxygen at 2L via nasal cannula, nebulizer treatments with albuterol/ipratropium every 4 hours, and IV corticosteroids. He is complaining of shortness of breath but states it is slightly improved from yesterday.

matrixMatchItems.title: Oxygen Saturation increased from 90% to 94% on 2L NC
Patient reports feeling less short of breath than yesterday
